title: Week 1 Game 1: Purple Edges Green in Season Opener
author: League Correspondent
summary: The Fall League season started with a close match between Purple and Green. Despite Green's strong start led by Matt Spear and Tavian Barrino, Purple's balanced attack secured a 71-64 victory, powered by ball movement and four players in double figures.
content:
Week 1 
Week one of the Revolution Fall League got off to a sizzling start.
There were surprise wins, forty-point showcases, and even a fifty-four-point clinic by an early MVP contender.
Let’s get into the action.

Game 1: Purple vs. Green
The first game started hot and heavy.
The dynamic duo of Matt “Swiss Army knife” Spear and Tavian “The Smooth Operator” Barrino led Green to an early lead. Spear got to the cup at will, while Barrino showcased a lights-out shooting stroke. Meanwhile, Brody Snow scored timely buckets.
Despite their play, Purple held a 37-35 lead at halftime.
In the second half, Purple stretched that lead.
Ball movement and player touches were the secret sauce to their offensive output. Logan Tobin led the way, followed by “Mr. Consistent”, Kolby Bradford. Rounding out the scoring action were Kaleb Swetty and Fin Mitchell.
The quartet each scored in double figures, leading to a final score of 71-64, Purple.
Purple Top Performers
Logan Tobin - 18 points, 9 rebounds
Fin Mitchell - 13 points, 9 rebounds
Kolby Bradford - 16 points, 3 rebounds, 4 assists, 3 steals
Kaleb Swetty - 15 points, 4 rebounds, 2 steals
Green Top Performers
Brody Snow - 10 points
Matt Spear - 29 points, 15 rebounds, 3 assists, and 2 steals.
Tavian Barrino - 22 points, 7 rebounds, 4 assists, 2 steals

title: Week 1 Game 2: Black Blows Out Light Blue; MVP Candidate Shines
author: League Correspondent
summary: Black dominated Light Blue in a decisive 98-54 victory. The team's MVP candidate delivered a spectacular 54-point performance, establishing Black as the early favorite in the league. Light Blue's Jibril Abdullahi led his team with 23 points.
content:
Game 2: Black vs. Light Blue
This game was a one-sided affair.
Black blew the doors off Light Blue, winning 98-54. The Black team was led by an early MVP candidate, who put on a scoring clinic. His fifty-four-point performance put the rest of the league on notice. Black is the team to beat.
Light Blue Top Performers
Jibril Abdullahi - 23 points, 4 rebounds, 3 assists, 2 steals
Matt Riordan - 13 points, 9 rebounds, 2 assists, 3 blocks
Black Top Performers
MVP Candidate - 54 points, 15 rebounds, 5 assists, 3 blocks, 3 steals
Kyle Mayor - 15 points, 3 rebounds, 2 assists
Brandon Bigelow - 10 points, 3 rebounds, 5 assists

title: Week 9 Finale: Yellow Stuns Light Blue in Final Regular Season Game
author: League Correspondent
summary: The Yellow team pulled off a shocking upset against the heavily favored Light Blue squad. Led by Manny Robertson's dominant 23-point, 15-rebound performance, Yellow won 71-60, locking in the final regular season standings.
content:
Game 1: Light Blue vs. Yellow
Light Blue came out flat, and Yellow capitalized. They led by as much as fifteen at one point. Yellow’s center, Manny Robertson, was a beast on the boards. He was a force to be reckoned with. Yellow’s bench came up big, too. Kassian Prior, Jack Lloyd, Kyle Mayor, and Brandon Bigelow came up big in the upset, too.
The final score was 71-60, Yellow.
Light Blue Top Performers
Jibril Abdullahi - 28 points, 4 rebounds, 3 assists, 3 steals
Matt Riordan - 17 points, 9 rebounds, 2 assists, 3 blocks, 2 steals
Yellow Top Performers
Manny Robertson - 23 points, 15 rebounds, 3 assists, 3 blocks
Kassian Prior - 11 points, 15 rebounds
Jack Lloyd - 12 points, 3 rebounds, 2 assists
Brandon Bigelow - 10 points, 3 rebounds, 5 assists
The Alta Group Player of the Game - Manny Robertson

author: League Statistician

content:

title: Warden's Wisdom Invitation: Mindfulness for Life
author: Warden's Wisdom Team
summary: Warden’s Wisdom, a mindfulness-based coaching service, offers an invitation for self-examination: Stay curious, stay open, and minimize judgments for a life well-lived.
content:
This recap was brought to you by Warden’s Wisdom, a mindfulness-based coaching service to help you overcome anxiety and stress with simple, customized mindfulness practices.

Warden’s Wisdom Invitation of the Week: “It’s okay to examine yourself. An examined life is a life well-lived. But be mindful of the approach. Stay curious. Stay open. And minimize judgments. You are a human after all.”
